title: Amazon Blackwater
subtitle: The home of Neon Tetras and Discus Cichlids
description: For half the year, the Amazon River floods the surrounding jungle. Fish literally swim between tree trunks and falling leaves. The water is tea-brown as decaying foliage releases tannins. This makes the water extremely soft and acidic, leaving bacteria with almost no chance to survive.
ecology: The dark coloration of the water provides small fish with protection from predators. Falling insects and the fine microfauna in the leaf litter form the primary food source. Plants hardly grow here, as the dark water allows very little light to penetrate.

title: Lake Tanganyika Rocky Coast
subtitle: Clear water and endless stone deserts
description: Lake Tanganyika in East Africa is the second oldest freshwater lake on Earth. Its rocky coasts drop steeply and offer countless crevices and caves inhabited by highly specialized cichlids.

conditions.flow: Surface movement, but calm inside caves

ecology: The water is extremely rich in minerals. Filamentous algae growing on the rocks are the most important food source. Every rock cluster is stubbornly defended as territory. Wood or soft sand play almost no role here.

title: Southeast Asian Peat Swamp
subtitle: Dark, shallow, and densely overgrown
description: These shallow, stagnant waters in Indonesia and Malaysia are extremely acidic and protected by dense vegetation. They often dry out partially or are heavily influenced by monsoon seasons.
ecology: Many labyrinth fish (like Bettas or Gouramis) originate from here. They have learned to breathe atmospheric air, as the warm, stagnant water is often oxygen-depleted. Floating plants further darken the water.
